action: I want to automatically and periodically execute aggregation and data update processes
reason: To reduce manual work, prevent missed processing and human errors, and achieve stable business operations
acceptance_criteria: Batch execution functions can only be configured by authenticated administrators.
Jobs for execution (aggregation, notification, integration, etc.) can be registered.
Job IDs must be unique.
Execution schedules can be specified by time, daily, weekly, or monthly.
Cron format schedule specification is supported.
A manual execution trigger function exists.
The status of running jobs (Waiting / Running / Success / Failed) can be verified.
Job execution history is stored.
Execution start and end times are recorded.
Execution duration is recorded.
Execution result logs are stored.
Error logs are stored upon failure.
Logs are stored in tamper-evident storage.
An automatic retry function for failures exists.
The number of retries is configurable.
Alert notifications are sent upon retry failure.
A locking mechanism exists to prevent simultaneous multiple launches of the same job.
Job dependency settings are possible.
Subsequent jobs stop if a dependent job fails.
DB update processes are under transaction control.
Parameterized queries are used as SQL injection countermeasures.
Timeout settings exist for external integration jobs.
Long-running jobs are executed via asynchronous processing.
The design ensures execution load does not impact the production system.
Jobs are paused if CPU/memory usage limits are exceeded.
A batch processing queue exists.
Queue congestion status can be monitored.
Redundant configuration for the execution environment exists.
Re-execution is possible in case of server failure.
Changes to job settings are recorded in the audit log.
Job deletion is a logical delete.
Deletion history is stored.
Integrity checks of execution data are performed.
Input parameters are validated.
Job registration via API is possible.
The API requires authentication.
Rate limiting is applied to the API.
Internal information is not returned during API errors.
Success rates of batch processing are monitorable.
Execution statistics reports can be output.
Execution history is searchable.
Retention periods for execution data can be set.
The overall operational status of batch processing can be verified on a dashboard.
The design ensures no jobs are lost even under high load.
